At first I didn't know what to think (starts off kind of slow) but once you get into it, it's a BLAST. I paid 99 cents for this and it's already worth much more than that! Definitely a game I'd recommend.

11007675.review:
Note avant la MàJ du 22/10

Graphismes: 9/10
Loin des jeux ultra high tech avec fonction 3d intégrée et d'autres trucs inutiles, les graphismes,quoique pixellisés, restent bons, ce qui a le grand avantage de pouvoir laisser la possibilité à toutes les configs de faire tourner ce jeu.

Gameplay: 10/10
Peu de commandes (gauche, droite, sauter, tirer, super tir, souris pour viser), mais une fois qu'on y joue, on se rend compte qu'on a pas besoin de plus. Un point original reste le fait que le déplacement n'est possible qu'entre deux plateformes, quel que soit le niveau.

Duée de vie: 9/10
L'histoire est courte, franchement. Malgré ça, la durée de vie de ce jeu est conséquente. Après avoir fini l'histoire une fois, on peut la faire avec un autre "mode" (Vario mode). Une fois fait, on peut chercher les 24 pièces de cd jaunes pour avoir les 6 cd/pouvoirs, sachant que le dernier permet une troisième fin à l'histoire, et permet de débloquer les modes Overdrive. De plus, le mode Endless est excellent, avec la possibilité de voir son classement online

Histoire: 7/10
Comme je l'ai dit, elle est très courte mais étrange.
En gros, The Alchemist( un des personnage de Savant), en allant dans sa tour, se la fait "pirater" la pierre philosophale par Vario (un autre des personnages de Savant, en gros un "bug" dans l'univers). The Alchemist doit remonter la tour tout en détruisant des objets animés par la pierre philosophale )et n'ayant qu'une envie: tuer leur ancien proprio), puis détruire a pierre (SPOILER!)[spoiler] Sauf si on a réussi à débloquer tous les cds, car dans ce cas on peut aussi reprendre la pierre, ce qui finit le jeu sans affronter Vario [/spoiler] , ce qui détruit Vario.
J'avais bien dit bizarre.

Note personnelle: J'adore Savant. Le fait de pouvoir jouer avec ses musiques est tout simplement épique

Note finale avant la MàJ du 22/10/14 : 8,75/10

Avis post 22/10

Il y a eu une grosse mise à jour du jeu le 22/10, rajooutant un cd, 2 niveaux, dont un boss, et des améiorations.

Graphismes: 10/10
On reste dans un esprit de jeu 2d "à l'ancienne", à savoir plutôt pixellisé, ce qui garde le grand avantage de pouvoir laisser la possibilité à toutes les configs de faire tourner ce jeu, mais avec quelques améliorations.
J'ai particulièrement apprécié la refonte du mode Overdrive. Avant la mise à jour, toute son apparence passait par un filtre de couleur (son masque changeait lui aussi de couleur). Avec la mise à jour, chaque Overdrive a un skin associé, de sorte que ce masque reste blanc.
Pour rester sur l'Overdrive, j'apprécie aussi le fait que le niveau max n'a plus une seule couleur, mais qu'il change de couleur continuellement, et de manière fluide.

Gameplay: 9.5/10
Peu d'améliorations, mais un ajout dans les derniers niveaux (les nouveaux) de pouvoir détruire les plateformes, ce qui rend le jeu plus compliqué, ce qui le rend encore plus excellent.

Durée de vie: 9/10
Bien que le contenu n'est pas énorme, cette mise à jour permet de se rendre réellement compte que le jeu sera mis à jour à chaque nouvel album de Savant, ce qui prolonge énormément la durée de vie de Savant

Histoire: 8/10
Une grosse prolongation de l'histoire avec deux nouveaux niveaux.

Dans ces niveaux, après avoir vaincu Vario en mode normal (pas en Vario mode), le haut de la tour explose et envoie l'Alchimiste dans l'espace.Là, il doit détruire tous les ennemis (comme d'hab), puis il arrive au niveau du Samourai, un guerrier robotique extrêmement puissant (il dépop, même si t'as tes 3 coeurs). Ce niveau est un pur Die and Retry, car si tu ne sais pas ce qu'il va faire, tu ne peux pas le vaincre. Pour ceux qui veulent savoir comment le vaincre: [spoiler]Premièrement, il vaut mieux avoir le 6ème cd, afin de passer les niveaux Overdrive, et lui infliger mass damages.
Au début, il faut charger sa jauge de puissance en sautant (pouvoir d'un des cds), et aller tout de suite après sur la plateforme de droite.Il détruit la plateforme de gauche, qui va réapparaître.
Il va ensuite lancer une attaque qui va le faire rebondir de plateforme en plateforme (je rappelle qu'il dépop tout), il faut donc faire gauche-droite-gauche-droite-gauche-droite-gauche. Il va ensuite détruire la plateforme de droite, et va projeter la vôtre vers le haut.
Il va ensuite aller sur celle de droite (qui sera réapparue), et le haut du corps va se détacher afin de vous attaquer(un coup,qui vous tuera)
Là, je conseille d'aller vers celle de droite afin de récupérer des débris et monter l'Overdrive en attaquant les jambes du samourai, jusqu'à ce que le haut de son corps soit tout près de vous. Là, lancez l'attaque ultime(les 5 tirs super puissants) sur le corps du samouraï.
Il va perdre de la vie, se téléporter, et de nouveau vous attaquer.
Allez rapidement sur la plateforme de gauche en sautant(et en continuant à sauter) afin de recharger votre barre d'énergie.
Attaquez le corps avec les gros rayons.
Sautez sur la plateforme de droite et rechargez votre barre d'énergie
Il fait mine de lancer une attaque, mais il n'a en général pas le temps.
Relancez votre attaque ultime si il s'approche trop de vous
Ensuite, le haut et le bas vont se rattacher, et i va partir vers la gauche.
Si vous n'êtes pas sur la plateforme de droite, allez y.
Puis, il va faire une destruction de plateforme.
Il va détruire la plateforme de gauche.Puis celle de droite.Puis re celle de gauche.(en tout, il détruit 8 plateformes).
Attention à changer de plateforme dès que l'autre apparaît, car à moins que vous ayez des réflexes de fou, vous ne pourrez pas l'éviter au dernier moment.
Enfin, il y aura 5-6 secondes de calmes, où vous devrez recharger votre barre de puissance.
Puis, une plateforme apparaîtra sur la droite, et un "mec" balancera un rayon destructeur sur l'une des plateformes (aléatoire, et une seule à la fois) une fois toutes les 5 secondes (à peu près)
Attaquez le mec, car il permet de charger votre overdrive très très rapidement.
Au 4ème rayon, le samouraï va de nouveau envoyer son haut du corps vous attaquer.
Balancez votre attaque ultime, puis rechargez la en sautant(balancez l'attaque au bon moment, car les rayons vont continuer (il en balancera encore 3 ou 4, mais il arrêtera après ces 3 ou 4).
Continuez à l'exploser avec votre attaque ultime. Enfin, ça recommence depuis le début, et ce jusqu'à ce que toute sa barre de vie soit vide. [/spoiler]
SPOILER!!!
[spoiler] de toute façon, après l'avoir explosé, il réapparaît, vous balance vers le sol, vous fait retraverser toute la tour en chute libre, et vous finissez en dessous du premier étage, transpercé par une lame brillante.  [/spoiler]

Bref, ce jeu est encore mieux qu'avant.

Note finale: 9.125/10

10986887.review:
For a game with a two dollar price point and seemingly simplistic gameplay, there's a surprising amount of depth here. Your first few runs through feel pretty powerless, but every power that you unlock adds an entirely new mechanic to the combat, giving a sense of actual progression that can be somewhat lacking in cheaper indie games like this.

And, as pretty much every other review has stated, the soundtrack is outstanding! There's a dynamic element to the music that changes as the enemies get more aggressive, which stretches the admittedly small music choice (7 songs, total) out quite a bit. 

At the end of the day, I've gotten hours of enjoyment from a game that I paid two dollars for. If I spent that at an arcade, I'd be done in less than twenty minutes. I'd solidly recommend this game as a decent time killer.

10984963.review:
I bought this game because it was available for only 99 cents on the Summer Sale, and I didn't expect a whole lot to come from it. I was almost not going to buy it at all, because I thought it would be a waste of money. But alas, Aleksander Vinter is one of my favorite musicians, so I decided to buy it.

It. Is. Fantastic. Truly fantastic. The gameplay is smooth, the aesthetics are outstandingly well-done, and I can't stop playing it. After the main story is beaten, you unlock Time Attack and Endless modes, and Endless is where I spend the most of my time. The gameplay is fast-paced, and the soundtrack is almost perfectly paced for it. There is a song or two that can underwhelm the action of the game, but this brings me to my favorite part of the game; the soundtrack is 100% interchangeable. You can convert one of your own songs to .OGG, rename it, and replace any of the songs in the main folder that have the prefix "ost", and also edit the english configuration file to change the text as you please, so that you can fight your way to the top to your own beats. I personally replaced "ISM" with "Nightmare Adventure" and "Melody Circus" with "Mother Nature".

The menus, however, took me a second to figure out. Settings is an icon in the corner of the home screen, and Master Volume only means the sound effects, not the actual Master Volume, so it doesn't affect the background music. It actually had me bummed for a bit, because the sound effects were severely overtopping the great music, but I didn't think I could affect the SFX itself without also affecting the music. This too, however, is fixable in the english configuration file.

Over all, I got a drop-dead EXCELLENT bargain for 99 cents. I would have gotten an amazing deal for it's original asking price of $1.99. I would have even paid up to $4.99 for this game, though maybe that's just my inner Savant Fanboy speaking. So if you have a couple bucks to spare, pick up this game. You won't regret it.

I have mixed feelings about this game.

As for the graphics: they're beautiful. The animation is smooth and the character design is great. I never get tired of saying of how great they are for a game that's worth a few bucks. And while it depends on your personal music taste, the music is great to listen to as well. 

I was really dissapointed to find out how short the game was. I managed to beat story mode in 30 minutes! Not only that, but I find the gameplay very repetitive. It's always the same map, and the same enemies. The setting changes a little as the gameplay goes on, but the only thing that changes is the color and difficulty of the same enemies over and over again.

I also find it frustrating how the game doesn't expand to fullscreen, unless it's just happening to me. My mouse often goes off-screen and I end up moving the window and having to re-adjust the whole game window.

Overall, the game is fun for a few hours then it just gets old unless you enjoy playing repetitive games. I hear that there are more features coming in the future- I'm interested in checking them out.

10780824.review:
Savant é um jogo com um conceito interessante, trilha sonora MUITO bacana e CURTO. Todo mundo que joga ou jogou este jogo vai dizer isso.

Mas acredito que, pelo estilo adotado, pelo conceito do jogo, a duração do mesmo é perfeita. Não é um jogo para quem espera  uma história complexa ou grandes desenvolvimentos, é um jogo para quem quer ação rápida, curta e divertida, sem enrolação. Tem história? Sim, tem um enredo básico (com uma "surpresinha" no final), mas o que importa mesmo aqui é atirar, desviar e pontuar.

Não sei por quê, acredito que esse jogo cairia muito bem dentro de um arcade, lá na década de 90, com um monte de gente querendo entrar no ranking. E não digo isso por mal, mas esse jogo tem todo um "feeling" de arcade, talvez pelos controles, talvez pela jogabilidade, preciso jogar mais para tirar conclusões sobre isso.

Mas os controles são simples e, realmente, não precisa de melhoras ou mais botões/opções de movimento. Todos os comandos respondem bem e a jogabilidade é bem bacana.

A arte do jogo é bem trabalhada e remete à jogos 2D da era 16/32 bits e a trilha sonora é um show à parte, combinando perfeitamente com a ação e o sistema de jogo.

Recomendado para quem gosta de jogo curto e rápido, mas não abre mão de diversão, boa música e gráficos 2D bacanas. :)

10598333.review:
Not sure where to start.

The story mode is extremely short- like 15 minutes long, and consists of just 3 stages. Although, it will probably take you at least 40 minutes to complete. To me anyway, there was a definite learning curve. It will probably take you tons of tries to complete the story mode unless you're like some machine. But once you beat it, it will be easy. I probably died 30 times trying to complete it. After I beat it, I played the story mode again, and didn't die once in the whole thing.

After completing the story mode, you will unlock the vario version of story mode, time attack, and endless mode. Don't think you're done once you beat the main story. 

If you like dubstep, you'll love the music and probably the game. If dubstep isn't your thing, you probably won't like this, but there are some more mellow songs. Unlocking the 6 CDs which give you special powers is very fun, challenging, and also a cool and unique concept. I still have the last CD to unlock.

I would give the game a 7.5/10. It doesn't have the most content and the design is simple, but it's very entertaining and definitely worth the price. It's even better for a sale price of 99 cents.

10579790.review:
Divertido, adictivo y frenetico son las palabras que describen mejor a este juego. Si lo que buscas es divertirte, buenos desafios y un juego bueno y barato, pues Savant - Ascent te recibira de brazos abiertos. Puede que el modo historia no dure mas de 20 minutos (si es que lo terminas facilmente), pero no te preocupes, cuando lo pases contaras con el clasico modo Time Attack y el Endless Mode. Tiene unos simpaticos y pixelados graficos con buenos escenarios, sencilla y buena jugabilidad, una gran dificultad (cuando hablamos de los logros, desbloqueables, etc.) y un soundtrack realmente bueno. A medida que vas jugando encontraras varios fragmentos dorados de discos, cada disco desbloquea un soundtrack del juego, y cada soundtrack te brindara otro poder, ademas los logros sera lo mas desafiante que encontraras en el juego, ya que son realmente dificiles de conseguir, y creeme que durar 5 minutos en Endless Mode (uno de los logros) no es nada facil.

En resumen, Savant - Ascent es un divertido y adictivo juego para pasar el rato y desafiarse a uno mismo, ademas de barato.

10412531.review:
Brilliant! I didn't think of this much at first to be honest. When I started it and realised that the character wasn't moving freely, only hopping between two possible spots while shooting enemies, it seemed very limited to me. Everything was happening in this confined area without the possibility of going anywhere. That early impression wasn't fair. As it turned out the strength of this game lies elsewhere.

The gameplay is generally about shooting swarms of enemies with your character's powers, who can fire magic missiles from his hands at really high speed. Lots of sweeping action as you clear them out while dodging them when they charge. Music plays an important role in this game and while I may not normally listen to this sort of music, it's very appropriate for such a fast paced game.

The real fun comes from obtaining new abilities and learning how to use them effectively to become even better. In fact... Every ability you unlock is something new, but having a big impact on the gameplay. It forces you to change your habits to get used to the new mechanic, as it gives you decisive advantage that helps you make even greater progress. The abilities are unlocked along with new music tracks that you collect as you play and once you have them all, you can also obtain a secret ability (if you figure out how or look it up) which leads you to possessing unbelieveable power that you'll need to prove your true ability in the Endless mode.

Overall this was fun!

10322946.review:
Симпатичная простенькая игрушка. Все что надо делать это перемещаться между двумя точками и поливать огнем всех врагов вокруг. Для ясности насчет перемещения - нажав кнопку "влево" оказываемся на левой позиции, нажав "вправо" на правой. Ну и можно еще нажать вверх и тогда перемещение между точками произойдет не по прямой, а прыжком. Никакой ходьбы здесь нет.
В итоге получается такой красочный простенький "устреляй их всех" экшен с небольшим элементом тактики. Раздражает только очень маленькое поле зрения, большинство врагов постоянно летает где-то за экраном, но в двух метрах от нашего затылка.
При этом игра ОЧЕНЬ КОРОТКАЯ. Здешнюю "кампанию" я прошел за 23 минуты. То есть больше чем за бакс ее брать смысла нет (хотя в ней хорошая картинка и музыка). Хотя, если она затянет, то дополнительные развлечения имеются - из врагов можно выбивать диски, которые анлочат интересные абилки (я за прохождение открыл половину наверное), есть пара дополнительных режимов - Time Attack и Endless. Так что несколько часов фана точно найдется.

10239067.review:
Savant é um jogo que tem uma boa faixada, e acompanhado pelo bom preço pode enganar qualquer um. Infelizmente, ele é um jogo repetitivo e extremamente curto, com uma história simples junto com sua jogabilidade, embora possua uma boa trilha sonora composta pelo artista de dubstep conhecido como Savant, e daí que vem o nome do jogo.

Basicamente, você possui dois lugares para se posicionar, e alterna entre eles para se desviar dos inimigos que tentam atacá-lo, e usando seu ataque, você deve destruir todos para avançar durante o jogo. Infelizmente, essa jogabilidade simples tem algumas falhas, que é não ter disponível um modo full screen, e sendo um jogo usuário do mouse para realizar seus ataques, vez ou outra você vai acabar clicando fora da janela por acidente. Sua visão também é bem pequena, sendo bem difícil assim localizar os inimigos que vêm de encontro ao seu personagem.

Como já dito, a trilha sonora é muito boa, porém não possui muitas faixas. São dubsteps que variam bastante entre um e outro, que dão uma sensação de adrenalina durante o jogo, e isso é algo que acaba aumentando ainda mais a vontade de jogar. 

Um jogo muito barato com uma proposta interessante, ao unir waves de inimigos e uma boa música, mas infezlimente com uma jogabilidade cansativa, repetitiva e com algumas falhas. Se mudassem uma coisa ou outra (como a movimentação), ele poderia ser um jogo bem mais atraente.

10090798.review:
You may say that this is not your kind of game. And that would be the only valid excuse not to buy [i]Savant - Ascent[/i].

It used to be even cheaper, when its story mode had just 2 levels and a boss, which some people may complete in an hour. (Later another level and a boss were added)

But just completing the story gives you... 0 achievements, because that's just the beginning. Other game modes is where it gets competitive.

The gameplay in [i]Savant - Ascent[/i] is much deeper than it may seem at first. There is this iterative process where you get far enough in the game to gain a new power, so that you are able to get farther in the game and gain a new power...
And all 6 of these powerups change the game enough that it stays interesting all the time. They all add a new mechanic, synergize with each other, but still can be controlled with very few buttons, and I really adore that elegance.

You can get 6 hours of gameplay out of this, if you want to explore everything. That's the time it took me to get 100% achievements.

Oh, and there's also soundtrack that you're bound to like, no matter what genre is your favorite.

★★★★★★★★★☆

9956622.review:
A great old school elevator shooter!

Once you get a handle for the stiff, but rather simple controls this game can be a real blast. Just keep in mind that the game costs two dollars for a good reason; it is incredibly short. Plus, after unlocking the four CDs in story mode (which can be done in about 30 minutes) the game gets rather easy as each gives the player a new power. Once you've mastered the control scheme and found the other two CDs in Endless mode this game can be beaten in under 4 minutes (my best is 3:58). 

With that in mind, there are still many reasons to come back to Savant - Ascent after you've beaten it. There are Time Trial and Endless modes which both offer plenty of arcade style fun. If that's not enough, turn on GOTY (or goaty?) or Vario (think Wario) modes for some unusual added variety.

If you've read all this and you're still on the fence, this game probably isn't worth 2 dollars to you. Otherwise, just buy it already. It's fun and it'll cost you less than a fountain drink.

Muy bueno.
Lo recomiendo siempre que sepas qué es exactamente. Es un juego de platafornas y disparos de tipo [i]bullet hell[/i]. Es muy rápido poniendo a prueba tus reflejos y atención.
Algo importante a destacar es que es un juego para pasar el tiempo (kill time). La campaña es muy corta, pero ese no es el fuerte del juego. Tambien cuenta con modos Time Attack (contrareloj) y Endless (sin fin) que son los modos en los que pasé más tiempo. La idea es divertirse viendo cuanto tiempo puedes sobrevivir, no hay muchos niveles u otros objetivos más que matar a todos.
La vida útil se alarga, si te aburre rápido, con objetos ocultos (fragmentos de CD) que debes colectar a lo largo del juego en sus diferentes modos y que te otorgan [i]power ups[/i]. Tambien tiene unos logros dificiles que te tendran ocupado bastante tiempo.

Recuerda, la campaña es corta y quizás pases mas tiempo jugando los otros modos viendo cuanto duras en morir. Es una buena opción para pasar el tiempo.

9805790.review:
I got this as part of [url=https://www.humblebundle.com/?androidbundle9]Humble Bundle: PC and Android 9[/url] which at the time of writing is still available for the next two days at the beat the average price. I'm really enjoying this game, there's three things that stand out for me:
[u][b]It looks great[/b][/u]
The pixeley graphics, animations and detailed backgrounds are all lovely. The style and humour are also a delight. Trying to describe it in a catch all term I'd go with gnarly-fantasy-techno-gothic-retrogamey.
[u][b]It sounds great[/b][/u]
To go with that ludicrous description of it's visual style is an equally awesome soundtrack to boot. It's not incidental either, given the main collectables are CD pieces, this game was clearly made with some fantastic music at it's core. There were elements of the music that made me nostalgic for experiences I have never quite had, I recalled playing Amiga games as a child in a concrete studio with smoke machines and lasers.
[u][b]It plays damn good[/b][/u]
Blowing stuff up, chaining kills, overcoming challenges are all very satisfying. The powerups add interesting an meaningful changes to the character quickly increasing your effectiveness.

I've only just got as far as completing the story a few times over. (Once you've done it once, it's an affair that only takes a couple of minutes.) I'm now trying to get the 5th and 6th CDs and get some other achievements.
It's a short game, but what's there is really good and I expect to be spending way more time with this in Time Attack and Endless mode trying to get the last of the collectables and make my way to the extra little secrets and powers that come later down the line.

I’m also heading back to Humble Bundle to download the soundtrack right now, because I know I’m also going to want to listen to it when I’m away from my computer.

9802921.review:
Savant writes a Skrillex-inspired brand of electronic music referred to on his website as "EDM," which is about as vague and accurate as saying Cannibal Corpse plays "rock." As an aside, it's not dubstep that producers such as Skrillex and Savant put out, either. It's a post-dubstep genre called brostep. You'll find no use of low-frequency oscillators in their music. But I digress.

You could call Savant - Ascent a twin-stick shooter. You could also call Savant EDM or Cannibal Corpse rock. Do you see where I'm going with this? This game loosely resembles a twin-stick shooter in that you control your character's position with one stick and fire with another, but holy god is this a bad twin-stick shooter. The player has virtually no control over their movement, for one thing. This is problematic when the game is based around the concept of killing things and not letting them kill you. The in-game tutorial (which is not programmed to detect a gamepad) uses the word "dodge" to refer to the limited lateral movement possible, but unlike dodge moves in sensible action games, the dodge movement confers no invincibility frames. Not much of a dodge as it is a spastic move from one static position to the other. Normally this wouldn't be a problem, but the whole point of the game is drowning you in enemies and then giving you not-enough time to kill them before they come zooming at your face. One would then assume that one could safely dodge out of their way and continue playing. One would be wrong. Movement throws the player into enemies as often as into safety.

On a related note, the right stick (or maybe the mouse? I don't know how you'd even attempt to play this without a gamepad, honestly) controls your shots AND the camera movement. Seems useful, right? Help ya see what yer shootin'. Except for the aforementioned game design philosophy of "drowning you and enemies and then giving you not-enough time to kill them before they come zooming at your face." While you were aimed at the bottom of the screen trying to kill one of the enemies with 5 zillion hitpoints because those are the ones that drop the MacGuffins and actually let you progress like some sort of jackass, the game spawned 30 grunts and now they're coming right for you oh god the pain! Also you only get 3 HPs. I can't be sure, but I'm pretty sure you get minimal-to-no invincibility frames when you take damage. Look what you get for trying to get a new upgrade and a new terrible song to listen to! You get PUNISHED, SON!

"You should give this game more than 17 minutes before you write a review, you jerk!" No. Any game that makes me ragequit twice in less than 20 minutes because I got killed by something that I was off-screen, couldn't see coming, and couldn't possibly avoid doesn't deserve any more of my time.

Apparently if you beat the "story mode," you unlock Endless Mode but I fail to see how that would be fun for anyone who dislikes cheap deaths.

This is a bad game with bad controls and a god-awful soundtrack.

But at least the sprites are pretty.

9794199.review:
Aleksander Vinter, better known as Savant, is a Norwegian EDM artist who releases a  copious amount of albums. He has released 7 LPs and 3 Eps since 2012. If you're a fan of his music you probably already know this, if not you should look him up on youtube. I am a fan of the songs "Butterfly", "Melody Circus", and "ISM", all of which are featured in Ascent.

Savant - Ascent is essentially a a bullethell game,, except that you don't have freedom of movement--you can only move between two locations. It's really short--the story mode is like 10 minutes if you don't die. That said, it's also really challenging, and between the time trial and the endless modes, there is a really good amount of replayability for such a cheap game. 

The music is great, obviously, although it's a shame that there isn't more interaction between the game and the music. In summation, this is a challenging, addictive and fun game, and I would recommend it to any fans of Savant.

9775604.review:
This game is amazingly better than one might suspect of a music-artist tie-in game. Savant Ascent is the kind of cruel mistress that brings out the most deliriously self-serving masochist from within you, and rewards it with the delicious satisfaction you crave: but only after you have endured every sweet punishment it has thrown at you. If that analogy sounds overtly sexual, then I implore you to view that as a re-enforcement of how devilishly brilliant this game is, and only in some small part as a reflection of my own character.

The game is not perfect; the difficultly curve is steep, the 'story mode' is a tad short to be called a story, and the final boss is more than a little odd (Although Savant fans will get a kick out of the in-joke reference). However to re-use the previous analogy: she's cheap and you get exactly what you deserve. She's also got some surprises you would never expect, and not in the venereal-infection kind of way!

Buy it, growl at it, then submit. You will love this game!

9775115.review: The music amazing in this game.

9774520.review:
After looking at some reviews, I expected Savant - Ascent to be a very short, competent shmup with a good soundtrack. After going on a five hour binge of playing the game, I can contest that it's not just a competent game, but rather great at what it does. The controls feel extremely responsive (I've used mouse & keyboard), the animations are well-excecuted, and there is no dull moment.

You start the game with only a rudimentary set of skills – and it's hard in the beginning (or at least was for me), however, you unlock extra abilities by progressing through the levels and game modes. You can probably beat the Story Mode in half an hour or so, but that's where the fun begins. Time Attack Mode is over quickly and good for a short game, while Endless Mode is where the real challenge lies – i.e. in defeating neverending ways of enemies, each wave stronger than the last.
The skills you unlock are tied in with six different music tracks you can change at will, all of which are great (and I'm not a huge fan of electronic music, in general).

It took me five hours to unlock all the different skills and get every achievement in the game – extremely good value, considering the price point of the game, I'd say. One thing to consider is, however, that this will be most enjoyable if you are into score attack games – beating the game once does not take very long, as I said. If you want to challenge yourself (and beat your friends' score, maybe?), though, this might be the ideal game for you.

Game is great, fast-paced and great once you get good at it. The levels are challenging, and the music is enough to keep you going through the whole thing.

Problem is, the golden robots with CD pieces have WAAAAAY too much health. When you're getting mercilessly attacked by 500 other robots then you don't have the time to chip away at the gold enemies for a CD piece. Once I was blasting at one and dodging in an attempt to avoid the other bots and then the gold bot vanished and then I was twatted in the face by an oncoming one and then I died. The way the controls are mapped gives me finger strain and the camera only moves when you're shooting, so when you gotta clean out the CD pieces you missed at the end of the level it's awkward to try and see them.

But I get a little further in the game with each attempt, and I do believe I can eventually finish it. So I still reccommend you buy this for the 2 bucks.

9703129.review:
Ураганный шутем-апп про алхимика который хочет вернуть себе свою башню. Для этого ему придется убить... Vario... при этом он сам (как и противник) похож на Гая Фокса, а все остальные враги это роботы и роботы-утюги)) (так же можно включит режим "козлов" и они будут выглядить как козлы). Вот такой суп. Сюжет минималистичен и показывается только в начале и конце игры. Геймплей тоже не затейлив: атака, сильная атака и 2 вида прыжка. Все время мы стоим по средине комнаты и отстреливаемся от врагов, можно прыгнуть в право или лево, а так же прыгнуть по дуге. И в игре всего 3 уровня... которые можно пройти за минут 20... но фишка тут вот в чем: что бы открыть одну способность надо собрать компакт-диск (способность + неплохой трек). И в одиночной игре можно открыть только 4 из 6 песен.
Пройдя основную компанию вам открывают 2 новых режима: на время и безконечный режим и режим Vario.. Если режим времени представляет из себя чуть усложненый режим кампании, что бы проходить как можно скорее и хвастаться перед другими.
А вот безконеный режим хоть на первое время и похож на такой же как и в других играх, но тут есть свои секреты... 2 последние песни можно открыть только в этом режиме. Для этого вам надо продержаться минут до 4 и активно уничтожать золотых роботов. Это не так просто как может показаться. 
Режим Vario активируется только в режиме истории. Персонаж сразу одевает маску поверженого врага и начинает атаковать по иному, да и концовка будет иной. 
Но и это еще не все! Последняя песня дает вам новую атаку - притягивать врагов к себе. Идем в одиночную компанию проходим ее, но в последнем уровне использует эту спец атаку и притягиваем к себе филосовский камень. И теперь если начать игру в любом режиме, то притягивая к себе врагов вы будете "прокачивать" героя и так до 5 уровня. Это наверно единственный способ дожить в режиме выживания до 10 минут (ради ачивы)

So there are gold records in every level on enemies that won't attack you. You gather these records and you unlock special abilities to make the next playthrough easier and easier. The enemies always come in the exact same way, and you can't collect multiple gold records from the same enemy making it a good way to make replaying easier since you won't have to concentrate killing the tough gold record character and instead focus on staying alive until you see a new gold record holder. Plus those records unlock more songs and you can choose which one you want to listen to while playing. All in all a really good game in the first place, then add Savants music on top of it and its excellent especially for 2 dollars!

9556841.review:
Игра, которая и на игру-то не очень похожа - я бы сказал, что Savant - Ascent является интерактивным музыкальным альбомом, посвященным творчеству известного в узких кругах музыканта Александра Винтера. 
Что тут имеется: мы играем за Алхимика, механизированного мага, который стремится заполучить силу Философского камня. Нам предстоит отстреливать многочисленных, но не столь разнообразных врагов на протяжении аж трех уровней. По ходу дела можно подбирать куски CD, которые даруют нам новые способности. 
Казалось бы, полный провал, а не игра, но есть одно "но": весь этот скоростной геймплей происходит под отличнейшую электронную музыку вышеупомянутого Александра Винтера (известного также как Savant). Все вместе это дает ощущения, которые я в последний раз испытывал при игре в Contra: Hard Corps.
Вердикт: хоть игра мне и понравилась, я не буду ее кому-либо рекомендовать. Но если вы поклонник электронной музыки или просто хотите порубиться в олдскульный шутем-ап, то можно потратить на нее два бакса.

9537359.review:
A fun 16-bit styled game that has a fantastic Dubstep soundtrack and will amplify your adrenaline in minutes.

[b]Savant - Ascent[/b] works perfectly fine and runs smoothly, however it does have some modern technical issues:

- [b]Maximum resolution[/b]: 1650x1080 (won't up-scale, so forces the chosen resolution in-game)

- [b]Volume level controls[/b]: Only Master and music levels, but no effects level controls, which is shame, as the in-game music is great, but you can't hear it so well, the game is based on 2 channel audio only, so all effects and music is mixed in stereo and not sent to centre (third) channel. 

- [b]No soundtrack[/b] (officially) [b]with purchase[/b]: Although you can pull the Ogg's easily from the installation folder, this isn't exactly the official OST and there's no FLAC version available at present.

- [b]Secondary screen and/or BigPicture[/b]: Losses focus a lot when the mouse moves outside the play window, which can't be avoided and can only be fixed by the DPad Studios

It might be a great value indie, but these minor issues to probably most, are actually bigger issues to me, because they stop me from enjoying and playing this game until it's fixed.updated.

[i]Support and buy this fun budget indie game, but with caution[/i] []¬__¬]

9355823.review:
A great yet short indie title, Savant Ascent is a grat title if you enjoy shoot-em-ups. The gameplay starts simple enough with basic bullet streams controlled by the mouse with a simple manuevering system involving jumping between two platforms. However, collecting 4 track pieces will unlock addition power to your arsenal which is where the mechanics start getting interesting.

I enjoyed the music, but if you don't care for dubstep or heavy beats it will get grating on you. The spritework is well drawn and colorful, though very light on frames of animation.

The main game is only 2 stages and a boss, however a time attack and survival mode are available after the main game is completed. Add to it the unlockable powerups though collecting tracks, it does have some replayability, though I do wish there was more levels and enemy types to mix up the gameplay more. But given the pricetag, Savant Ascent is a great buy and well deserving of its GOTY award.

I saw this one sale for around 0.35 I think? I bought it because it looked fun for 35 cents. I was right.

The game is 2 levels, with a third acting as a boss. You left click to shoot your bullet hell at the baddies (There is about 6 types of baddies) and push A or D to shift between one of two points to avoid attacks. 9295059.review:
A great indie game that combines both intense gameplay and immersive music (especially if you love music like dubstep) to create an awesome experience.
The game is tough on beginners at first. A difficulty setting would have been nice to newcomers but the difficulty in the game is there for a good reason. The game is very short. When you've completed the story mode, you will find out that it takes about 5+ minutes more or less to beat the game. Even so, it took me one and half hours to beat the game after many failed attempts. Making the game difficult was obviously a good call so persons can have a longer playthrough of the game, and with enough practice beating the game won't feel as difficult as it first did. 
The gameplay is pretty simple, basically shoot the enemies while keeping a steady evasion rate, but beware, it's harder than it actually sounds. I find the keyboard and mouse mouse works better than a game controller because the camera moves around the screen very irritatingly with a controller.
I personally would have liked a longer story mode for the game, at least two levels. The two other modes are great for score attacking but nothing else. Also there are only 2 resolutions, since the artwork of the game is pixel art, if you don't have the supported resolution, there will be a noticeable difference of how well the games looks. 

For $2 you'll be getting a pretty good but very short game. If you're a fan of shoot em up or bullet hell games, you'll definitely love this game. If you're not fan of the genre but like intense games, this is well worth the experience.

Rating: 8/10

9189029.review:
The Music is mind melting, the gameplay is excellent, and the length? Just right. You can probably finish the story mode in around 30minutes. But it's the modes unlocked after that, that make the game great. A whole new character, endless mode, and a time attack for those speedrun inclined. It's an over-the-top semi-shmup. It's worth the current $2 and at the current 99c, a steal. You can easily spend a few hours in the game just unlocking everything and seeing how long you can survive in endless mode. 

A few gripes with it, is obviously its length, a lack of epilepsy warning (This game has a lot of flashy lights and colours be careful), and as you progress further, it gets harder to keep track of enemy positions and attack states. However this may be because I may not be the best at this game. 

Overall a wonderful little hidden gem in a sea of shitty games on steam. The music is wonderful, pixel art amazing and story lacking but suitable.

8/10

9178776.review: Incredibly cheap and incredibly addictive. Ascent is a fantastic little gem with an outstanding soundtrack by Aleksander Vinter (aka Savant). This game sees you play as the alias of Savant who originally appeared on the album art for Alchemist. The controls are rather simple, but fluid, using the mouse to fire magical missiles at enemies and the "wad" keys to dodge. As you progress through this short storyline (2 enemy stages and a boss stage) you can collect CD fragments which snap together to unlock a new ability and a new soundtrack option which can be changed at any time on the pause menu. Songs include Kali 47, Melody Circus and Back to The Phuture which combine classical, rock and electronic into a fantastic meld of genres. Once the story has been completed, "Time Attack" and "Endless" game modes are unlocked, providing more replay value. These are certainly challenging, but also give you the oppurtunity to unlock 2 additional soundtracks and abilities which may make it slightly less punishing. For £1.49 there's no reason you shouldn't pick up this game. You'll certainly get more entertainment out of this than a TF2 key for the same price, and I strongly reccomend you check out the rest of Savant's music if you're interested in that type of thing.

9162373.review:
Firstly, this is not a long game in the main mode.  It took me about 20 minutes to get through it, and then a little over 5 for my first time attack win.  But there's an endless mode as well, and some more unlockables.
The game is a frenetic shooter - you have two places to stand which you can move between as you blow away hordes of enemies around you. It starts out pretty basic, but as you unlock CDs, you get new abilities which do change up the gameplay. The endless mode especially has that 'just one more time' feel that is great for a game.  It's not a complicated game, but it does have more depth than you'll see to start.  And once you get the groove, it'll hook you.  Just make sure you like dubstep.

9136084.review:
Savant - Ascent arcade tarzında olan ve atari zamanlarından hatırladığınız, rekor kırmak için jetonları feda ettiğiniz oyunların hissini tekrar yaşatan bir oyun.  Hikaye modu oldukça kısa ama time-attack ve endless modlarıyla(hikaye modunu bir kere bitirince açılıyor) bir süre daha kendini oynattırıyor dolayısıyla 2 dolar verdiğinizi düşündüğünüzde hatta şu an %50 indirimli olarak aldığınızı düşündüğünüzde paranızın karşılığını veriyor.(Bir humble bundle değil tabi.) Savant'ın oyun içi müzikleri ise aynı isimdeki bir sanatçı tarafından yapılmış(diğer yorumlarda sanatçının yeni albümünün tanıtımı için bu oyunun yayınladığından bahsedilmiş?) ve yeterince güzel.

9118783.review:
Savant- Ascent is a short game... Very short. 
But don't get me wrong. It might be short, but it is also very hard and addicting. 
You will want to test your skills by improving your time and highscore after every failure. And you will fail.
At least at the beginning... And then, you will fail again... Ok, you will fail a lot. But you won't give up. The music won't let you.

And what about the music? Well, the music is fantastic. It is made by Savant himself. If you don't know him, you can check his music at his YouTube channel (http://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5ur2L6Zu4oCShmtFw9UTfQ) or his Soundcloud (https://soundcloud.com/aleksander-vinter). It might look like I'm promoting him or something, but it is worth it. Because you might thank me for that.

Let's talk about the art style now. It is great. It reminds me a lot of Castlevania: Symphony of the Night. And if you know what I'm talking about, I don't need to talk about it anymore. 
But if you don't know what I'm talking about, here is a little summary for you. The art style looks like it draws from Renaissance and Gothic styles of architecture. And thanks to that, some of us might feel nostalgic about this game. Others will say that the style looks good and I can't agree more. I will just add that it is very atmospheric.

So, is it worth paying the amazing amount of 2 €?
Yes, it is. You will have fun and that's the most important thing about games.

Playing it, the whole style of the game seems to be from Savant's love of old-style games, combined with his fantastic music. All-in-all, it plays like a stationary shooter, where you must fire at enemies around you before moving to the next area. 9094194.review:
Savant is a simple game that runs an average playtime of about 45 minutes. And, I suppose that is what’s to be expected for a 2 dollar indie title. Though, here is the thing.

Savant for me, was an amazing purchase. If you are someone that 'needs' a good story with their indie game, you might want to look elsewhere. This is a game that is all about style. With its odd look of Cyber Punk-Fantasy and loud Dubstep blaring in the back ground to get your adrenaline running. Savant is more akin to games such as Realm of the Mad God or even Hotline Miami. With its tight controls and literally taking no time to lean. It’s an 'aim with the mouse cursor' game, a game that is fast to get into, and even faster to get out of. 

Finally, while it may not be as hard as Hotline Miami, Savant is still pretty challenging. But that is exactly why I would still suggest picking it up. I mean... its only 2 dollars! When games are cheap and have such a great amount of polish on them like Savant does, it’s hard to say no.

8860238.review: Most games add a soundtrack to their gameplay. Savant Ascent does the opposite: it adds gameplay to a soundtrack, and it matches perfectly. 8842305.review:
It's short, but it's sweeeeeeet.

It's simple, too - mouse aims where you shoot, and you have two spots to stand on, and two ways of moving between them (roll and jump). That's about it, but it works really well, and the game is just about the right size for it not to become stale (helped a lot by the music :P).

I personally love the soundtrack and now own the Alchemist album. A fair warning - it's an electro/dubstepy kind of thing, and I know some people don't like that. If you don't, you might want to consider skipping this title, due to the main draw being the oddly simple cohesion of music and gameplay.

The graphics are high quality pixel-art, and very well animated too. Most importantly, it's actually easy to tell what's going on on the screen, even when things get hectic.

For two euros, this one is a bargain. Price-to-fun-factor ratio is trought the roof.

8701128.review:
How can you go wrong for $.99?

I went into this game with no knowledge of "Savant" or any knowledge of what this game was. I saw it on sale for 99 cents and bought it. It took me all of 30 minutes to beat it. There was no story beyond some weird character falling off of a tower and coming back to fight his way back up it to destroy whatever shiny round thing knocked him off. I later found that the "hero" character is actually the alias of some musician (Aleksander Vinter), and the character is dressed up as he dresses on stage. And of course this game just happened to be released on the PC just days before his new album...surprise surprise.

+ Really nice art. Too bad there is so little of it.
+ Apparently there will be additional content added for free. Leaderboards for a 20 minute game that doesn't penalize death? Hurray!
+ If you are into this artist "Savant" or dubstep, you will love the music, apparently...

- This seems like a showcase for the artist, his music, and his on-stage persona, not about a complete game with compelling gameplay, story, or characters.
- There is no substance to this game. Your progress in the game continues at the last death, thus removing any impact to death. You simply crunch through the easily defeated waves of enemies until you grab enough pieces of "cds", a ridiculously obvious allusion to the modern real world which makes this game feel even more like part of an album promotional campaign of some kind, giving you extra powers. Then you die, new powers completed/retained and then you start anew with no penalty whatsoever.
- End boss is ridiculously easy. This fits the general sensibilities to this game though.
- This is an iOS port of a game developed in just five weeks. I should have known...

I would skip this and buy a good $1 Humble Bundle instead. You are sure to get more value and quality gameplay in a good Humble Bundle than with a 30 minute promotional game for an artist developed in just five weeks...

8644180.review:
"Savant? What's a Savant?"

Let's pretend, shall we? Let's pretend you, like me, had no idea of what Savant is before buying this. You've stumbled across this page because it's cheap, you don't have a lot of cash left to spend, you want a new game, and the art for this looks slick. The trailer is sweet and for two bucks it seems well worth the risk.

So, is it, then, worth your money?

I'd say yes. Savant is what I'd call an arcade-ish shooter, and you can beat the (regular) story mode in one sitting, easy. The music is good, the gameplay with mouse and keyboard is tight, and I can think of far worse ways to spend two bucks. The game is simple yet has enough depth to warrant a few more sittings of gameplay, and the mechanics are easy to pick up. Oh, and did I mention the art here is gorgeous? Great stuff, pixel-ish with good detail work.

Now, the downsides. First off, I had another reason for buying this title. I had just got a controller to hook up to my PC and I wanted more games to play with it. First off, it doesn't automatically detect the controller, you gotta switch to it via the options. Second off, the controller set up... Isn't great. The right thumbstick, which you use to aim your shots (if you've got a 360 pad as I do), automatically zooms the camera out in that direction, something that only happens with the mouse if you edge your pointer far out. Grabbing CD pieces is wonky, and, overall, I gave up after about ten minutes and used keyboard and mouse instead. Speaking of that, you can't rebind keys. The defaults are fine, but that's always a nice option to have, and it's a bit disappointing when a dev doesn't allow for it.

Other than that, the only other real gripe might be length. It all depends on what you expect from a two dollar title. For me, this game exceeded my expectations and provided a fun evening's worth of play, and there's still content I haven't unlocked. But the story mode is easily beat under an hour, and if I had to guess on how long it would take me to unlock EVERYTHING, skill aside, I'd probably bet on four to five hours. This might disappoint some, but I guarantee you that the slick gameplay, good presentation, and sweet music makes up for it.

So, we come back to the question, what is Savant? See, that's what makes this game notable to me. Savant is a band, and, though I've never heard of them before playing this, their stuff isn't bad. That makes this a tie-in game of sorts. And if you're like me, you probably grew up with a lot of god-awful tie-in games in your childhood. This title is an exception, and that is a pleasant surprise to me. Combining slick gameplay, great 2D graphics, and hectic action, Savant stands above most every other tie-in game I've played and is a title I would recommend to anyone willing to drop two bucks for a night's worth of fun.

So what is this? Its a music-based shooter! Its pretty tough at first, as you die in three hits, but there's a neat system to warn you where enemies are coming from. Once you've nailed all the features down, its a breeze to get through this short game, but a BLAST. You'll be rocking the tunes as you smash the baddies. As you kill enemies, they sometimes drop disc pieces that unlock new tunes, and powers! I enjoyed every moment of this little gem, even through the difficulty.

Interesting note : the guys who made this, D-Pad Studios, are also making a game I am long awaiting : Owlboy! Check it out, it looks like a really nice Metroidvania-style game with old school pixel art. Buying this will no doubt help them continue this endeavor.

Music : 10/10 Excellent music blends perfectly with gameplay. Gotta like Dubstep though. To me, Candy for the ears.
Gameplay : 9/10 A bit frustrating a first, you die really easily and you just have to start over. Powerups help overcome this, and you'll feel like a badass blasting everything away. Its a very good system with no bugs to speak of. Aiming with mouse works very well.
Story : N/A not really relevant in this case, as its basically an arcade game. Same as why story isn't very important to Mario Bros.
Graphics : 9/10 Sweet looking pixel and drawn art all-around, though very limited in scope. Don't expect much variety. 

This game nets a 9/10, but is very short. Worth the pricetag though.

Short story mode, meaning you can literally complete the game in 5 minutes if you're good. Endless mode I haven't tried yet but presumably it goes on for some time.

Despite the shortness, this is quite an action packed game. Purchased for 79p in the Steam Winter sale 2013, it's very addictive and meaty when you hit the enemies with your blasts. Similar to Bleed in regards to how powerful you are in comparison to the enemies, yet you really only have two weapons, a stadard energy blast, a huge blast which can take out harder foes. You collect pieces of CDs in order to upgrade your powers, which you can see in my gameplay video. Each CD gives you a new ability, and in story mode there are 4 of them, in Endless mode, you can get the last 2. 

A very modern dubstep and some chiptunes in the soundtrack, of which the files are simply OGG files in the directory, meaning they can be copied away and played elsewhere.

Feel free to look at my video of my run through the game. Spoilers for the ending of course, but you'll catch the drift of it in no time.

8568033.review:
At two dollars, I'm not going to compare this game to AAA titles, or even AA Indie offerings. So, I'll compare it to other things you can buy for two dollars, like a large soda or 1/7th of a movie ticket. I've never seen a large soda or 1/7th of a movie ticket last me 2 hours without overstaying its welcome, so on those grounds alone Savant - Ascent is more than worth your purchase. I've put two hours into the game and still feel excited, even encouraged to keep playing it. 

The story is non-existant, but the sprite work and music are stylish and energetic, which is exactly what an arcade style game should be. Gameplay is simple enough, but challenging without being pretentious or overbearing. Story mode will take you all of 15 minutes to complete - 5 if you're skilled - but time attack and endless mode make this awesome game last. It's something I'll play once a week, and for two dollars you can't beat that.

8538998.review:
There are things this game gets wrong: no native support for 1920x1080 resolution, for one, or the slightest help in picking the correct resolution for the fullscreen mode so that the aspect ratio matches. And, the worst, the unskippable slow camera pan at the start of the third stage of the story mode. And to unlock the main point of the game - the endless and time attack modes - the player has to finish the story first. The first time, the camera pan is OK. But after half a dozen attempts (there are unlimited continues, thank goodness), it becomes infuriating. Let me play already!

But once the story mode is cleared, it becomes a very addicting score-attack action game. No more cutscenes, no more unskippable camera pans, just pure gameplay. The story mode works as a tutorial to the basic game mechanics. For a novice like me, surviving two minutes in the endless mode is a challenge.

The character moves only in a very limited way: jump or dodge to the adjacent platform. There doesn't appear to be any danger of missing a jump.

The pricing, 2€, is competitive with its price on the mobile platforms, but I would think it's easier to play with a proper controller.

8460224.review:
If you like games for their stories, this is probably not the game for you. There is not much of a story, the emphasis is on the gameplay and presentation.
If you dislike the music that this guy makes, or these genres in general, then this game probably isn't for you. The game is basically built around this guy's music, and the music is probably part of the appeal to the people that really enjoy this game.
If don't like "retraux" games where you die a lot and the controls are simple, this game probably isn't for you either. You may die a lot, you may not like the controls, you may not like the gimmicks.
If you're looking for the game of the year, don't buy it. This is a short fun game, nothing deep or super substantial that you'll think about days after you've played it. 

But if you want a short, fun game with inspiration from arcade games where it's all about having fun for a short while until you insert another quarter, buy it. It's two dollars at most, and it'll most likely be worth it.

It also helps if you don't find the music too obnoxious. I honestly like it, and the fact that you can switch soundtracks whenever you want was nice. I also drooled a bit over the pixel art, the main character and enemies aren't those crappy "retro" 8-bit platformer characters that are just square stickmen that you see in some games nowadays. This is real Metal-Slug-like pixel art, though they've taken some liberties.

But the gameplay is most important. You will get a new power that changes the way you play slightly every five minutes, on average, for half an hour. After that it's basically the same thing, but by the time that happens you'll have two difficulty levels, one mode that changes the graphics slightly, and you'll have unlocked two additional game modes that I haven't really explored yet.

To me, it was definitely worth it. I recommend it. If you watch the trailer and find that this isn't your game, don't buy it.

8428449.review:
Savant was a pleasant surprise for me. I did not expect much, considering the low price, but the game really delivers.
It plays a bit like an old school 2D arcade game, the graphics and pacing definitely remind me of that era.

Graphics are very sharp, controls are simple and responsive, and the music, which is more or less the focus of the game, is great.

My only problem with the game is, considering the nature of enemy attacks, I'd much rather have the view zoomed out at all times (or at least have an option). The camera is always zoomed in VERY close to the character and the only way to see enemies is to pan with your cursor, which you're already using for shooting 100% of the time... So even though you're given off-screen markers for charging enemies, that's still far from ideal.

Also, no Steam overlay on Mac (yet?), meaning no achievements or screenshots for Mac users.

8390028.review:
A very quick, and fast paced shoot em up type game that incorporates music into a large part of the gameplay. The art work was interesting and in the most recent update the "intro" scene gives the player an idea of the storyline behind the game all the while leaving a sense of mystery. Gameplay is indeed fast as it took me about 15 minutes to actually beat the game. However, replayability is present in the scoreboards for highscores, timed runs, and other various features of the game. 

That being said I would have liked to see more from the developers in the aspect of the music. Considering the fact that it is crucial to the gameplay, I would have liked to see more tracks available to play. It would add a lot more replayability in my opinion. However that is not enough to knock it down in my recommendation. Overall if you have some spare change and are looking for a fast paced techno shoot em up with pretty good music, Savant Ascent is for you.

8373895.review:
A friend of mine showed me Savant: Ascent and suggested I play it. I was not dissapointed. Savant: Ascent is a simple game, you stand on one of two platforms and shoot in all directions to kill enemies as they appear, dodging and jumping between platforms to evade them when they charge after you. The main game is very short, I completed it in just over an hour, but afterwards you unlock an Endless mode, bringing some more fun after you complete the story.

The story itself is minimal, you are the Savant, who's been kicked out of his tower, forcing you to fight your way back to the top and take revenge. Bare minimum, I know, but it works for such a short game.

The music and graphics are amazing, as you play you can aquire parts of CDs, which after you collect 4 you unlock a new track and a powerup you can use in subsequent playthroughs. My only gripe is the powerups almost make you unstoppable in the main story, but this is what endless is for.

Very recently, the developers added new content to the game and have fixed some of the controller problems, which is awesome, if more keeps getting added, it would make this $2 game even more awesome.

In short, this game is cheap, fun, and worth the $2 asking price. If you're looking for a good time-sink, this will keep you occupied for a few hours, maybe days.

8358098.review: This game is phenomenal! I hadn't heard of Savant untill this game, and boy am I glad I discovered him. This game is fast and fluid and makes you feel like a total badass, all while rocking out to Savant's music. You can unlock more tracks to listen to in the game by collecting CD pieces as you play and each CD also unlocks new abilities. The art style is gorgeous, the music is rockin, the gameplay is addicting, and even the achievements are awesome. You know those games that just hand out achievements for nothing? Or those games with achievements just for playing the game for a year? That aint here. These achievements are based on pure skill. And they are WORTH it. Achievements you can actually brag about. Tell your friends about this rad game (btw, it's only 2$ but it frequently is on sale for 0.99$).

8319855.review:
Wait, what ? D-Pad Studio, responsible for the beautiful but not yet released Owlboy, have actually released a game ? I recall them saying they'd paused the development of Owlboy in order to work on this game first. A move that doesn't make sense to me. Not that it's a bad game, but a game that can be finished in roughly in 1 hour. After that you still have Time Attack and Survival Mode, but I couldn't care less really. I usually play games for their story and when I finished the first level of Savant Ascent (or so I thought) it actually booted me back to the main menu, with the new gameplay modes unlocked. That's it ?! How the hell is that a story ? This game didn't raise the bar for action games. It didn't raise the bar for anything. And not that it's bad, it plays just fine, but it's so just frustratingly short and incomplete.

Oh man, Owlboy... Tears are streaming down my face if I just think about how they stopped development just for this game. A terrible mistake. Then again, maybe Owlboy wasn't meant to be. If this is any indication...

[Rating: 62/100]

8292549.review:
It's hard to review a game that's hardly working. when i started the game i pressed SPACE to get on with it. after a short intro the game than gave some text to explain the controls, again asking me to press SPACE to continue. however at this point SPACE was doing nothing and i was trapped on this tutorial text. So i tried the game pad and what do you know, the A button acts as SPACE. So than i continue to use my game pad to read the controls that are explained for the keyboard - the device that the game no longer allows me to use.

After that i was thrown into the middle of chaos, enemies coming from all directions, a game pad as my only choice for controls which i do not know how to use since the game never told me the controls for the game pad, so i'm blasting in all directions, some how taking hits without so much as a second of time to react and about 15 seconds after the start of the game i died. i barely knew what happened, it was over so fast. 

Now i'm not very fond of games where i see the GAME OVER screen within the first 60 seconds of launching it but even still, i decided to give it another try. Pressed START on my game pad to try again and there i was, blasting away in all directions, i managed to dodge a few hits, i think, but with only three i knew i wasn't going to last long. I got hit twice but still going, maybe 30 seconds of living this time and right before i could get hit a 3rd time, the game crashed.

to summarize the game play, you can fire in any direction, you can only move between 3 positions in the room and they are very close together, enemies spawn from all directions, and you can only see 1/6 of the room in the direction you are firing in. you mostly get hit by enemies off screen, out of view. it takes many hits to defeat a single enemy and some take quite a while to destroy. 3 hits and it's game over.

so, my time with this game was breif, confusing and a bit frustrating. bad design and bad programming. all i can say is at least the game was really cheap, so i didn't lose much at all. except for a piece of my soul...

8097633.review:
Jogo muito legal, curto demais o estilinho shoot' em up! 

No começo o jogo é difícil e desafiador, onde controlar seu personagem (controlar assim né, é só colocar pro lado para alternar entre as somente duas posições na tela, e pra cima para que ele mude de lugar da mesma forma anterior, mas pulando para o outro lado) será o seu maior desafio. Parece meio complicado de entender falando dessa forma, mas é bastante simples. Difícil aqui é desviar das trocentas "coisas" que voam pra cima de você na tela :D

Os gráficos são simplesmente lindos, mesmo que o plano de fundo seja na maioria das vezes fixo. Mas o jogo é muito bonito de se ver... a não ser que você tenha problemas de epilepsia! xD

Um contra desse game é que você joga o modo história 2x ( modo esse que possui somente TRÊS fases xD ) e já desbloqueia praticamente tudo do jogo. Sério! Até a a resolução do game (!) é um dos itens desbloqueáveis. No meu caso, joguei menos de uma hora e voilá: até o "Mário" apareceu pra me ajudar \o/

Prepare-se para morrer MUITO até pegar a manha do negócio e o tempo dos inimigos. Coletar os pedaços de disco ajuda um pouco, mas nada que faça o jogo se tornar fácil, fator considerado por mim essencialmente positivo.

De qualquer forma, vale o preço de promoção com certeza. Garantia de diversão, mesmo que por poucas horas. Recomendo.

8053019.review:
like many a review of this game on the internet, this review will just be about praise for this game.
this game, though not without flaws, is a shining example amongst indie games, and what just a few people can do in a short time.

firstly the good stuff:
-the game is visually impressive, being very colourful, flashy, yet simple. it easily cathces your attention.
-has a superb dubstep soundtrack and it only gets larger the more CD's you get (even if it is very limited)
-simple, easily understood controls that allow for well, simple and difficult gameplay.
-an upgrade system that simultaneously unlocks new abilities and songs for (via the aformentioned CD's)
-fun, addictive, arcade style gamplay that you can just pick up.

now the bad:
-while the contrls are easily understood, the game itself doenst convey how to use the controls very well
-there is no way to check the controls again once you've started playing.
-the graphics options are limited at best, and the resolution options are pretty bad.
-no online rankings as of yet (i hear that will be fixed soon though)
-severe lack of modes and different playstyles (the game couldve benefitted greatly from having an unlockable charecter or two).
-post game is severly lacking, and being so short, you need something to rope you players back in (again, unlockable charecters)
-and finally, you cant buy the soundtrack from steam. this seems like a minor thing, but after playing this for about 3 hours, i wanted to support the devs by buying there soundtrack, and lo and behold, you can't.

overall, the game, while a bucket load of fun and value ($2 people), it has an even greater amount of minor flaws that hold it back from being a perfect arcade-e, style shoot em up sort of game (i have no clue what genre this game is).
when the kinks are ironed out, and an extra charecter is added, then i can whole heartedly give this a 9/10, but until then its a 7/10.

8033987.review:
I never used to consider myself a fan of electronic music. On the contrary I actively detested it, but it seems I must have been hearing the wrong stuff, as more and more I find myself eating my own words as I fall in love with some immensely talented artists who make up the genre. The latest of those is Aleksander Vinter A.K.A Savant, a musician whose catalog is a blur of sounds and styles, and who is now the protagonist of his own video game: Savant Ascent.

A mixture of up-scrolling shooting and quick back and forth jumping, Ascent feels and plays unlike anything before it. Simple controls compliment the hefty difficulty as you attempt to stay alive through the onslaught of enemies, only able to move from one platform to the other as you make your way to the top of the tower. Enemies occasionally drop pieces of CDs, which on top of giving you a new slice of the soundtrack, rewards you with a new ability to use in combat. It's arcade nature lends itself very well to hi-score chasing, and the relentlessly quick pacing makes it hard to put down no matter how many times you die.

Savant Ascend is nothing less than an absolute blast, and although it's a short run (I beat it in an hour, though it will likely take less for most players) it is abundantly replayable whether that be going for a new best score, racing through time trials, or seeing how long you can last in endless mode. It looks brilliant, sounds even better, and costs less than a cup of coffee!

With blistering action, tight gameplay, and loads of wub wub, whether you are already a fan of Savant or not this is something you ought to be playing!

[b]You can read more of my writing on [url=http://kritiqal.com/2013/12/13/quick-thoughts-on-savant-ascent/]Kritiqal[/url].[/b]

7977737.review:
After playing Savant - Ascent for an hour I was immensed in its level design, mechanics and user experience of the game.

For a game that uses dubstep soundtracks I find that it does not distract me from the sound effects of the game. When the bass drops in certain parts of the soundtrack I can clearly define the audio for enemies spawning and enemies attacking. I think these small details really does bring out the enjoyability of the game.

I enjoy the rogue-like dungeon crawler paired with a shoot em up. I find that it brings a bond to the character to see it grow as it learns new abilities and techniques. Sometimes I was able to develop my own personal strategies to defeat levels after levels.

One intersting suggestion that I like to see maybe implemented in the future to add difficulty is I noticed that during the second level when you are in between two escalators that when one of the moves higer than the other i was able to dodge to that escalator even though it seems like it is impossible to roll up. I think that adding a constraint to that for the player to jump to the higher escalator instead of simply rolling would add some extra challenge. (Maybe it is already implemented, I have to play more and find out)

Overall I had a blast playing this game and the amount of thinking involved of creating a fun game through its plot, game mechanics and user experience and UI design won you a fan. Great work!

For $2, just buy it. Great gameplay mechanics, great soundtrack, great 16-bit artwork. The game is a simple concept (an elevator level) brilliantly executed, and everything is polished.

Extremely short story mode (can be beaten in ~5 minutes after your first playthrough), but the time attack and infinite mode add replayability, and the game is something that you can pick up for a couple minutes.

Like all great things in life, I wish there was more, but I'm happy they delivered an exceptional, small project, rather than provide a bigger project with less polish.

I will say ive Listened to some of Savant's stuff so it wasn't hard to pick up the flow of the game since its theme and composed by Savant (Aleksander Vinter) and themes arround his common style images of V for Vendetta and Mario both clearly and obviously refrenced. But to the game play, a smooth ryhtmically synced action shooter where the full map is avaible for attacking and to be attacked, and your limited between 2 spaces and 2 forms of dodging and neither of which make you invincible thus making who you attack and what you attack at what angles builds this into strategy and time management. The game is on its own very brief (i mean its 2 bucks i bought it by selling left over Trading Cards, lets be real) a rough time attack after beating the game twice ebbed at 4:11:33 (m/ss/msms), Endless Mode provides more abilites, powers and music than story mode will offer you to you keep going as well. The game does lack alot of diversity capping at about 5 enemies total but even then its the right amount of things to keep it on track smoothy and not over or under balanced. Also the art style feels very Sega Saturn which struck home with me personally, im aware its a much smoother newer astetic along with the days abilites but it has a feel to it that is very reminding, ya know what i mean?

Side Note (subject to change as they announce it): The devs have heard alot of feedback about the desire for a customizable personal track set the players can use and have with in 2 days of the game launch already gone back to discuss this feature due to the fact it is a music heavy game, Either way the musical aspect is enjoyable and has a flairing taste for most people even if its just one of the tracks.

7931684.review:
Команда D-Pad Studio, уже несколько лет разрабатывающая многообещающую игру «Owlboy» и забавную «Vikings On Trampolines», очень талантлива. «Savant - Ascent» — это очень красивый (как и все игры этих ребят), ураганный и весьма хардкорный экшен-платформер, наполненный волшебной атмосферой старых классических аркад из 1990-х. А такая низкая цена оправдана тем фактом, что сама игра довольно короткая, на хороших рефлексах все три её уровня можно пройти буквально за 10-15 минут. И как и в далёком детстве, подобные игры приятно затем перепроходить снова и снова, соревнуясь на лучший результат и собирая музыкальные диски. Мой текущий — сюжет пройден без единой смерти и заработано 10,5 миллионов очков. Пожалуй, единственным недостатком данной игры является отсутствие настроек громкости... 

Хотя в папке и лежит файл readme.txt со всей необходимой информацией и подсказками, расскажу о трёх важных моментах:

1. Не удивляйтесь всего лишь одному важному пункту в меню игры, «Story Mode» — его нужно пройти полностью один раз и тогда откроются два новых режима игры, «Time Attack» (рекорды прохождения уровней на время) и «Endless Mode» (бесконечное прохождение второго уровня игры до смерти главного героя).

2. Посередине нижней границы экрана находится индикатор, который заполняется по мере уничтожения врагов. Чем он больше, тем мощнее и красивее базовая атака на левой кнопке мыши (кстати, нет смысла постоянно жать на кнопку огня, отпустите, подождите секунду, нажмите снова — и во врага сначала полетит целый веер магических зарядов!), а так же круче альтернативная сильнейшая атака на правой кнопке мыши, которая этот индикатор истощает чуть ли не моментально.

3. Из мощных врагов выпадают специальные камушки — местный бонус. Добывается просто, нужно быстро прицелиться в выпавший камушек и нажать кнопку базовой атаки. Из камушков по частям собираются золотые диски, которые открывают новые атаки и музыкальные композиций в самой игре.

На этом всё. Ярких впечатлений вам!

7931135.review:
It's really short, maybe about 15-20 minutes long, but it's INTENSE.
Remember the old sidescrollers from the early 2000's? This is pretty much it, just really sped up.
It's basically a game meant to promote some artist called Savant and his music.
It's addictive, and it has an arcade feel to it. The music is probably the best part about this game, alongside the simple but rewarding gameplay.
Sadly, it's TOO DAMN SHORT, and there is no pause option.
They've announced updates for this gem, so it's just going to get better, hopefully.

Conclusion: it's great. Or better.

7929215.review:
From D-Pad Studio, the creators of the upcoming Owlboy, comes now "Savant: Ascent". Which is a great game. Let's just get that straight. NOW onto the review itself.

Savant: Ascent has a hectic, fast paced and heart pumping gameplay inside a wonderful aesthetic vision. Together with a fantastic soundtrack from the electronic composer Savant, all the elements of this game works and compliments each other extremly neatly. I find myself time and time again tapping my feet to the beat of the music, while at the same time ruining the rhyhtm with my excessive mouse clicking. Many, if not all elements in Savant: Ascent is tied together with a very simplistic, but very effective game design. 

The gameplay mechanics are simple, where the difficulty of the game is elegantly increased by more rapid enemy spawning and more powerful foes. I think the controls are tight and right to the point, and works well together with how the game tells you where your enemies are located at all times. It feels very balanced through all stages.

I recommend this game from the bottom of my heart. It is worth every penny (which is not that many). It is truly worth your time. I wish D-Pad Studio all the best in the future, because for you guys it is looking VERY bright based on what I've seen so far.

7920115.review:
After having played this for a bit, I can easily say this game is quite entertaining if you're looking for a quick fix. It does, of course, come with pros and cons:

Pros -
+ Straightforward, no bullshit game. Click and shoot and survive. Nothing to it! A nice, quick challenge for those seeking one without really jumping through hoops of fire.
+ The pixel art is pretty darn good. Haven't seen this kind of quality since the SNES/PS1. Even for a port, it looks nice.
+ Cheap. 2 dollars is pretty piddly so you can pick it up, play for a bit, and put it down at your leisure without feeling like you dumped an investment.
+ Upgrades carry over from death, so you can start again with stronger abilities if you unlock them.
+ It's a sledgehammer. The Savant music is an awesome addition if you're a fan of their works. It's in the title, so one has to assume people who play this are fans of the music too. Duh.

Cons -
- Goddamn difficult. Don't expect to beat this in one sitting. It picks up in speed fairly quick and can be tough to progress if you aren't paying attention.
- Only one track during the actual game, which can be pretty monotonous. (Not sure if you can change it in-game or not).
- Really fast. Like stated before, you have to pay attention and things can slap you silly if you're not looking.
- (Controller) Weird camera issues. You have to use the right stick for attack, but unless you abuse the five missile charge attack, you're constantly going to be off focus from your character, "hiding" some enemies from view, like the sawblades or Trapjaw.

Overall, its a great game, its cheap, its challenging, and it has Savant music. Quick thinking and a bit of luck will carry you far.
